Trust Your Instincts: If something feels off, trust your gut and remove yourself from the situation as quickly as possible.

Be Aware of Your Surroundings: Stay alert, especially in unfamiliar or isolated areas. Avoid distractions like looking at your phone while walking alone.

Use Personal Safety Apps: Install apps that allow you to quickly alert friends or authorities if you're in danger. Some apps also include features like location tracking.

Carry a Personal Alarm: A small personal alarm or whistle can draw attention in an emergency, potentially deterring an attacker.

Practice Self-Defense: Consider taking a self-defense class to learn basic techniques for protecting yourself. Knowing how to defend yourself can boost your confidence and preparedness.

Set Up Emergency Contacts: Designate a few trusted people as emergency contacts who can quickly check on you or come to your aid if needed.

Use Public Transport Wisely: If using public transport, choose well-lit and populated stations or stops. Be cautious when accepting rides from strangers.

Learn Basic First Aid: Knowing basic first aid can be helpful in emergency situations, even if it's just to administer immediate help before professional assistance arrives.

Be Cautious with Drinks: Never leave your drink unattended, and be wary of accepting drinks from strangers.

Carry a Self-Defense Tool: If legal in your area, consider carrying pepper spray or another legal self-defense tool. Learn how to use it properly.

Seek Help Immediately: If you feel threatened, don't hesitate to seek help from others around you or call emergency services immediately.
